item.text: [[EdTech Software]] does not need to be a [[Teaching Machine]]. It can also put people (learners and teachers) at the fore. It can be an aid to the socialisation of the learning process.
Surprisingly people like to be told what to do by robots.
item.title: Humans Prefer Robot Bosses

item.text: Pair programming (sometimes referred to as peer programming) is an [[Agile Software Development]] technique in which two programmers work as a pair together on one workstation.
item.title: Pair Programing

item.text: In the Viral Academy we use a modified version of [[Agile Project Management]] as our teaching philosophy and methodology
item.title: Agile Teaching

item.text: The idea that teachers can be replaced by [[Teacherbots]] is reminiscent of the idea that babies are better cared for in a [[Skinner Box]], or that politicians should be replaced by a software algorithm in [[Liquid Democracy]].

At first glance most of these proposals is horrific, but it is important to look into the details and motivations of much of this work, as there are important insights into how human [[Interaction]] should be designed.
Pair programming is about people coming together to make better code.
item.title: Pair Programing

item.text: In the [[Viral Academy]] we use the idea of [[Agile Teaching]] not to replace teachers, but to [[Democratise Teaching]].
item.title: Agile Teaching

item.title: Bots of Conviction

item.text: ALICE, is a natural language processing [[Chat Bot]]. ALICE stands for Artificial Linguistic Internet Computer Entity, but is more conveniently referred to as Alicebot, or simple ALICE - [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Linguistic_Internet_Computer_Entity wikipedia]
